description:
This fixes the cylindrical heigh and radius fields by adding a new function to calculate a periodic radius vector.  There was also an issue with collision between the ``center`` attribute of the data container and the ``center`` used in plot generation, so I switched the disk object ``center`` to ``_center.``  This may break other fields, but I'll look into those now.

For generating a cylinder centered at [0,0,0], with the following:

http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5039/

Cylindrical radius:

http://i.imgur.com/j9BmB67.png

Cylindrical z:

http://i.imgur.com/KsEBrBV.png
title: Fixing cylindrical fields.

content.raw: Any ideas for how we can test for this? Doing `dd['ones'].sum()` on a `fake_random_ds` dataset perhaps?
content.html: Any ideas for how we can test for this? Doing dd['ones'].sum() on a fake_random_ds dataset perhaps?

content.raw: I need to think about that, but we definitely need tests for this.
content.html: I need to think about that, but we definitely need tests for this.

content.raw: I don't understand why the plotting code is stomping on the `center` field parameter.  Can you show an example where that happens?  I'd prefer to avoid changing the name of the field parameter, as that may break user scripts.
content.html: I don't understand why the plotting code is stomping on the center field parameter. Can you show an example where that happens? I'd prefer to avoid changing the name of the field parameter, as that may break user scripts.

content.raw:
I think it's all about the data source, default field parameters, and
projection parameters.
content.html: I think it's all about the data source, default field parameters, and projection parameters.

content.raw: While debugging the cylindrical fields with a disk object centered at [0,0,0], I found that the center in the field function was showing up as [0.5,0.5,0.5].  I eventually that this was coming from the fact that I was querying this field from a call to ``ProjectionPlot``, which was setting ``center`` to [0.5,0.5.0.5].  Only when I passed ``center``=[0.,0.,0.] to ``ProjectionPlot`` did I get the center I actually wanted.
content.html: While debugging the cylindrical fields with a disk object centered at [0,0,0], I found that the center in the field function was showing up as [0.5,0.5,0.5]. I eventually that this was coming from the fact that I was querying this field from a call to ProjectionPlot, which was setting center to [0.5,0.5.0.5]. Only when I passed center=[0.,0.,0.] to ProjectionPlot did I get the center I actually wanted.

content.raw: So you supplied your data object via the `data_source` keyword argument of `ProjectionPlot`?  If so, I that's a bug in `ProjectionPlot` and shouldn't necessitate renaming the field parameter.
content.html: So you supplied your data object via the data_source keyword argument of ProjectionPlot? If so, I that's a bug in ProjectionPlot and shouldn't necessitate renaming the field parameter.

content.raw: Right now the `center` field parameter is used to define the origin of a coordinate system that need not align with the simulation coordinate system. It looks like currently in the plotting code this coordinate system is forced to have the same origin as the plot coordinate system. Maybe it shouldn't be doing that? Thinking out loud here: perhaps `ProjectionPlot` shouldn't use the `center` keyword argument of `ds.proj`, instead allowing users to override the center only via an entry in the `field_parameters` dictionary.
content.html: Right now the center field parameter is used to define the origin of a coordinate system that need not align with the simulation coordinate system. It looks like currently in the plotting code this coordinate system is forced to have the same origin as the plot coordinate system. Maybe it shouldn't be doing that? Thinking out loud here: perhaps ProjectionPlot shouldn't use the center keyword argument of ds.proj, instead allowing users to override the center only via an entry in the field_parameters dictionary.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1208/
content.html: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1208/

content.raw: I think it is ok if the ``center`` attribute from the ``data_source`` is used to set the center of the plotted region, but the problem seems to be that the reverse was happening and the center of the plotting region was overriding the ``center`` attribute of the ``data_source``.
content.html: I think it is ok if the center attribute from the data_source is used to set the center of the plotted region, but the problem seems to be that the reverse was happening and the center of the plotting region was overriding the center attribute of the data_source.

content.raw: Right, not using the `center` keyword argument on line 1232 of plot_window.py would fix what you were seeing, I think, and avoid having to rename the field parameters.
content.html: Right, not using the center keyword argument on line 1232 of plot_window.py would fix what you were seeing, I think, and avoid having to rename the field parameters.

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1210/
content.html: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1210/

content.raw: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1211/
content.html: Something went wrong, you should checkout http://tests.yt-project.org/job/py2.7-yt-3.0_testing/1211/

content.raw: Right, yes, ok.  I had noticed that some other similar attributes had been renamed with underscores and incorrectly guessed that it had to do with this.  I'll fix this.
content.html: Right, yes, ok. I had noticed that some other similar attributes had been renamed with underscores and incorrectly guessed that it had to do with this. I'll fix this.

content.raw: On second thought, I don't think it's as simple as that.  Getting rid of the ``center`` keyword on that line (and returning the field parameter names to what they were) actually causes projections of fields that use a ``center`` field parameter to break.  This seems to be because the data object that the field function sees is a ``YTQuadTreeProjBase`` type and not the original data source.  I return to my original thought that we are maybe overusing the ``center`` field parameter to mean both the center of the data object and the center of a plot.  Perhaps renaming to just ``_center`` is not the way to go, but I do think we need to distinguish these.
content.html: On second thought, I don't think it's as simple as that. Getting rid of the center keyword on that line (and returning the field parameter names to what they were) actually causes projections of fields that use a center field parameter to break. This seems to be because the data object that the field function sees is a YTQuadTreeProjBase type and not the original data source. I return to my original thought that we are maybe overusing the center field parameter to mean both the center of the data object and the center of a plot. Perhaps renaming to just _center is not the way to go, but I do think we need to distinguish these.

content.raw: Is this the same as `obtain_rvec`?  I recall that we went to using the Cython loop unrolling because it's pretty slow and costly to do this (with all the implicit array allocations) for big grids, or lots of times.
content.html: Is this the same as obtain_rvec? I recall that we went to using the Cython loop unrolling because it's pretty slow and costly to do this (with all the implicit array allocations) for big grids, or lots of times.

content.raw: Good catch.  For some reason I thought I'd fixed this one previously.
content.html: Good catch. For some reason I thought I'd fixed this one previously.

content.raw: This uses ``obtain_rvec`` to get the vectors.  I was originally going to do it that way, but it seemed like it was going to get quite messy.  I can do it that way if people think it's better.
content.html: This uses obtain_rvec to get the vectors. I was originally going to do it that way, but it seemed like it was going to get quite messy. I can do it that way if people think it's better.

content.raw:
I'm CC-ing @chummels on this one because it's possible he already fixed this and I unfixed it, but regardless, it is relevant to something he previously worked with and I want him to be aware.

So, it seems to me that there's a hierarchy here that should be codified and fixed.  I am not in favor of changing the field parameter name to `_center`.  I think the different objects at play are:

 * `data_source`
 * `ProjectionPlot`
 * `proj`
 * Domain / default field parameters

The question comes down to, what is the best way to make it easy for a person to specify what they want and then get back what they intended to get.  I think there are a few workflows.

 * Specifying a data source when creating a projection plot.  The field parameters of the data source should take precedence over the field parameters of the projection.  So imagine the extreme case of specifying both field parameters to `data_source` and then supplying a data source *and* field parameters to a projection.  I assert that the field parameters to the data source should override any from the projection when generating fields.
 * Specifying a set of field parameters when creating a projection.  These field parameters are the ones to use.
 * Not specifying field parameters.  The "default" field parameters should be used.  If the data object (i.e., the projection, or the newly-created "all data" source) have a "center" affiliated with them, this should be the center.  This will be the domain center in almost all cases.

Does this make sense?

Additionally, I am preparing a set of tests and a test framework that will test objects with periodicity.  We should probably also test that the radius fields are correct with them, too.  I will likely not do that in the first iteration, but my first iteration should be in today.
content.html:
I'm CC-ing Cameron Hummels on this one because it's possible he already fixed this and I unfixed it, but regardless, it is relevant to something he previously worked with and I want him to be aware.

So, it seems to me that there's a hierarchy here that should be codified and fixed. I am not in favor of changing the field parameter name to _center. I think the different objects at play are:

  • data_source
  • ProjectionPlot
  • proj
  • Domain / default field parameters

The question comes down to, what is the best way to make it easy for a person to specify what they want and then get back what they intended to get. I think there are a few workflows.

  • Specifying a data source when creating a projection plot. The field parameters of the data source should take precedence over the field parameters of the projection. So imagine the extreme case of specifying both field parameters to data_source and then supplying a data source and field parameters to a projection. I assert that the field parameters to the data source should override any from the projection when generating fields.
  • Specifying a set of field parameters when creating a projection. These field parameters are the ones to use.
  • Not specifying field parameters. The "default" field parameters should be used. If the data object (i.e., the projection, or the newly-created "all data" source) have a "center" affiliated with them, this should be the center. This will be the domain center in almost all cases.

Does this make sense?

Additionally, I am preparing a set of tests and a test framework that will test objects with periodicity. We should probably also test that the radius fields are correct with them, too. I will likely not do that in the first iteration, but my first iteration should be in today.

content.raw: The problem I see with this is that it then becomes impossible to give a data_source that has a center and also specify a center for the plot.  I think we simply cannot be using the same parameter.
content.html: The problem I see with this is that it then becomes impossible to give a data_source that has a center and also specify a center for the plot. I think we simply cannot be using the same parameter.

content.raw: In the hierarchy I specified, wouldn't the plot center then get passed to the projection, which gets overridden by the data source?
content.html: In the hierarchy I specified, wouldn't the plot center then get passed to the projection, which gets overridden by the data source?

content.raw: But I think in this case we wouldn't want it to be overridden, we just want both to be able to exist.
content.html: But I think in this case we wouldn't want it to be overridden, we just want both to be able to exist.

content.raw: Wait, let me be more clear: the plot center would be the center of the plot, but the field parameter center would be the center for the purposes of computing derived fields.
content.html: Wait, let me be more clear: the plot center would be the center of the plot, but the field parameter center would be the center for the purposes of computing derived fields.

content.raw: Also, does a ``proj`` object actually need a center anyway?
content.html: Also, does a proj object actually need a center anyway?

content.raw: Probably not, but it has one right now.
content.html: Probably not, but it has one right now.

content.raw: Alright, as long as that can all be kept straight, I'm fine with it.
content.html: Alright, as long as that can all be kept straight, I'm fine with it.

content.raw:
I think I found an underlying issue.  It was from some of my code from a while back, trying to address a related but not identical problem.

Here's the commit: be2141f80565 which is in my repo here: https://bitbucket.org/MatthewTurk/yt/commits/be2141f8056512887494f032e5e643f2d8a2b692

This script, I think, demonstrates it.  If you run it before and after my change, you'll see it.  http://paste.yt-project.org/show/5042/
content.html:

content.raw: Reverting this does indeed fix the problem.  I will update this PR.
content.html: Reverting this does indeed fix the problem. I will update this PR.

content.raw: Ok, I will commit to pushing this into the Cython, but that should not hold up this PR.  This is a pretty massive bug that needs to be fixed, if not optimized, ASAP.
content.html: Ok, I will commit to pushing this into the Cython, but that should not hold up this PR. This is a pretty massive bug that needs to be fixed, if not optimized, ASAP.

content.raw: Any reason we can't do the solution I implemented?  Or should that go in through a pull request from my fork?
content.html: Any reason we can't do the solution I implemented? Or should that go in through a pull request from my fork?

content.raw: Other than my one question below, I think this is ready to go in.
content.html: Other than my one question below, I think this is ready to go in.
